reviews.text:
An incredibly informative museum. Go and learn about his life, not just the war with the U.S. but everything before as well. Don’t expect the history to be spoon fed to you. There is plenty to read in English. If you are really interested in knowing, prepare to take your time to browse the kiosks at every exhibit. The small entrance fee is well worth it. 

As a side note, food and refreshments, convenient (WC) restrooms, and places to rest are abundant in the vicinity.

An incredible museum, leading me to tears on a few occasions. This is a must visit. Be sure to ask for a guide, the employees are very knowledge, and can guide you through the museum's narrative. I will never forget my conversations with the museum's staff, and the horrific struggles of their countries people. The star of the show may well be Ho Chi Min, and for good reasons, but the level of injustice will become apparent after you have toured this building.

I actually like this museum very much. It is a very well stuctured museum and you can learn a lot from it. It is quite small and can take your time to see everything. They close the door 10 minutes before the closing time and will rush you to be out by the closing time. (They literally stand behind you and tell you to walk faster towards the exit)
Not a bad museum if you want to know about Ho Chi Minh in detail. Entry fee is 40k but what I liked was the air conditioning after I walked around the mausoleum and near by attractions.

The Mesuem is in the complex of the Presidential Palace and we walked to it after seeing the One pillar pagoda, also in the same vicinity. 
There were some souvenir shops selling trinkets, knick knack and fridge magnets. Some are selling shawls and t-shirts. 
I had a good walk here.

Superb example of previous cultures and regimes at this stop. Great citadel/fort, and many temples, pagoda and gardens. Thien Mu pagoda on the banks of the Perfume River a must see. Plenty of nearby shops, cafes and restaurants as well as all the usual tourist trappings await you. A great day out. Recommended.

Impressive scale, recommend a guide. I've been to the Forbidden City in Beijing and had read reviews comparing this to it. IGNORE THAT. This is a very impressive citadel with many different gardens, building and palaces. It has not been fully restored yet and I believe they've been working on it for a long time and will be for many years to come. I think a lot of the significance was lost on our group because we didn't have a guide so that might be a good idea.

An excellent couple if hours spent here. Very interesting, Obviously the front part has been rebuilt since the US virtually demolished in 68 I think it was. Have a look at the before and after pics. Some serious history here and very well maintained.

We loved our visit to the imperial city. Amazing to think that this preserves remenants of an empire that still existed in living memory. We loved exploring the walkways and history this place used to hide. These beautiful buildings, thrones and gardens on their way to being lovingly restored. We were honoured to be part of that journey and would recommend it to everyone who has a few hours to spend learning more about the empire of Vietnam.

The most representative, iconic, and historic palace in Vietnam. Hue was the capital of the ancient Vietnamese empire, and the palace is its most important architecture. 
The imperial city has a thousand-year history and was heavily damaged during the war period. But the government properly rebuilt it and maintained well. Nowadays you can find the traditional and nostalgic aesthetic inside this amazing inner city.

We loved visiting the pagoda in our stop in Hue. Although my husband and I are quite tall so we were stopped a few times by other visitors from other countries asking for pictures with us.  We took a taxi there and then a dragon boat back down to the center of the city (dragon boat is much more expensive but price is negotiable). The pagoda has a lot of history and was gorgeous and well maintained. Would highly recommend this if you are stopping in Hue, especially because it is free to visit!

Very picturesque temple nearly overlooking the Perfume river  Walled landscaped gardens, Could be quite a peaceful place if there were no tourists (myself included).  No entrance fee, no hawkers chasing you to buy things. A few very well presented young monks walking around adding some serene ambiance to the whole experience.  An enjoyable trip by Dragon Boat along the Perfume river to visit.
A nice temple with the iconic pagoda in the front. There is a nice pond at the side and a small garden at the back. Very calming and soothing atmosphere.

Popular place with free entry. I felt that the serenity of the place was very much disrupted by the flocks of tourists coming by buses. If only we knew to be a little more considerate of the monks who spend their lives there :)

This is a popular free entry site which is pretty easy to tag on to a visit to the Imperial City as it is a short drive further down the river. We arrived by Grab car but many coach parties come here and you can of course come by boat taxi.

As others have said it can be busy here and although it is in a beautiful location, photographs will be hard to capture without other tourists in the way. Be patient or as we did, come when the weather is very wet!

There are steep steps at the entrance so access could be an issue and it is fair to comment that the pagoda itself is suffering from wear and tear. I found myself wishing to be able to see inside but there is only ground floor access.

This is a working Buddhist monastery and so it is probably more interesting to explore the grounds and see how the monks live now. There are still some beautiful parts to the monastery and it is  slightly bizarre that the car is the star attraction. The story behind the car isn't explained well for people who do not know enough about Vietnam's recent history.

In all, this is definitely a must see place in Hue and offers some modern as well as older history, some photo opportunities and a pleasant place to visit for an hour or two.

Gia Long Tomb is the quite far from Hue downtown. But its worth your try.
Large, unique and beautiful place :)
This tomb is set deep in the forrest so it has an amazingly cool and calm feel. The perfect balance of nature and architecture. It has amazing tombs and places you can relax and have a picnic.
You can definitely skip this one, far from interesting compared to the others.  One building is worth seeing, that's about it.
This is a great place ! The great king of Nguyen Dynasty who has found the country.
Very naturaly landscape and beautiful old building of Tomb of the King
Stunning place and do tranquil... A must for the historian..

The Tomb is not so far away from the city central and near the other emperors' tombs in the conservation system. It is a spacious green place with well conserved ancient architectures, which is great for both tourism and picnic.

Good conservation. No people around at all.
All you will need is read a bit about their history first to go other hand you won't understand nothing.
Fantastic experience of Vietnamese culture

Hardly anyone here.   In fact, I guess I  got here after it closed because no one was collection.  This place is certainly still in natural state and could use some refurbishment.   I still liked coming and well worth the effort to find it.
an amazing to visit. the emporer loved this place and you see this. the place is kept well. be sure not to pay parking... it's a public street
Amazing architecture and design, slightly too expensive for how small it is at 100,000 kip. Also you should aim to get there very early as it quickly gets filled with coach loads of tourists

On my mind the second best tomb I've visited in Hue. Definitely interesting, but keep in mind that almost all tombs have a very similar architecture, so if you visit the others you don't necessarily need this one.

This is one of the most interesting sites I've visited in Hue, and actually found this tomb more fascinating than the Palace and Citadel.  There's a unique style and architecture to this place that really testifies to how much the French had entwined themselves into Vietnamese life.  French culture appears not so much fused as forced upon Vietnam's extent, ancient culture.  The setting for the tomb is remarkable, absolutely picturesque.
Nice but not so many things to see

This spot has dope bun bo! The broth tastes really clean, with a lighter flavour that is popular in central region of Vietnam. Can tell her how spicy you want it. Locals slamming bowls most hours at this place or right next door on the street (lady with a big vat of noodle soup.)

Soup is good if you don't mind being overcharged or mind the loud techno music coming from next door at 630pm. Based on reviews here I tried to pay 30k, but the guy looked at me pretending to be confused and told me to pay 50k. Shame.
Very tasty bún bò (and that’s the only thing on the menu). Note that they close before lunchtime and reopen later in the afternoon.

Tasty meal and I liked it! But it was more expensive than we thought. We read it is 30K so went there to try. Ended up paying 50k each  instead of 30k. Asked them why and be told because it was big one. First of all, we didn't order large size (She didn't even ask or tell us about size so we assumed that it is regular 30k meal. Well, we should have asked then) second, even large one has to be 40k according to other people who left reviews here. They might increase the price so don't complain about it and I was happy of my meal but it would have been nice of her if she asked us which size we wanted. Anyway, meal was good and they could speak English well. So if you are okay with spending 50k, go for it!

This is one of those beautiful places where they serve one dish and one dish only but they do it very well. Delicious soup. Bun bo Hue. Absolutely worth a visit. Excellent firm and flavorful blood cake, fresh herbs, sprouts and pork meat Ina slightly spicy broth - but you can add a spoiler tone with the tableside chilies an chili paste. Yum!
Choose the set menu. It's a must. Really helpful with dietary requirements. The food was plentiful and flavourful. 10/10 :)
great foods! set menu is full of Hue. highly recommend!

Had a normal diner because I was afraid of getting a meal with meat again after explaining them that I’m vegetarian. They replaced the dish for me but the thing is, I still felt to keep attention to the food. Hence the 3 stars since the atmosphere is nice and busy.
Great food. Friendly staffs.
Great food great service. You will have a chance to try many local food of hue here

An excellent restaurant, it does look a bit touristy and is full of Europeans. We are here because we had been on the road in VN for nearly 3 weeks and felt like a change plus it gets good reviews. We went with an open mind, and where not disappointed. The   menu was very good with a big wine list, the house red and white were very drinkable. The bill came to about 850 k for two with drinks.

Clean and very good place for us. 
All 6 members was satisfied so much. 
I have a plan to visit again.

We went with the set menu to get a taste of everything. 6 courses for two ppl, with two passion fruit juices and two glasses of white wine. The whole cost was less than 23€ Beautiful food, kind helpful staff. Yes we would eat here again and again and again

The cheapest set menu was outstanding. The best meal we have had so far in Vietnam. The set menu was 6 courses for 210,000 Dong which was about£7.50. Service attentive and efficient. Also western set menus as well as a la carte. Vietnam even won the football.
Nice place with good food and service. Vietnamese and European style food on the menu.
Very good quality coffee. Nice view to the Perfume River. It will be nicer in February with cool weather holding a hot cup of coffee...
Good
Bỏ hoang rồi(2018), thật tiếc cho một tòa nhà, một vị trí đẹp. Các chị em làm nơi tập thể dục. Ở đây nếu làm nhà Trịnh Công Sơn rồi tổ chức các hoạt động văn hóa thì tuyệt vời.
View đẹp nhưng quán caphe đã không còn nữa
đã nghỉ

Not bad, not amazing either. Service was pleasant and prices good. Sushi pieces can vary in size and tend to be a little small. 

Wouldn't go back, unless they sorted out a few things. 

We've had some great experiences with sushi so this is a highish standard we have, so I would say this place needs to improve, and is a bit lacking in professional direction in general. As a hotel general manager this my honest opinion.
Best Sushi of my Life! Great Little local and great Service. Thank you for this amazing experience :-)

Great quality, very friendly staff, the food was really tasty and great appearance, the only down part was really the time it took to serve us, gaffe to wait a long time to get my food. But besides that everything was great including the prices. Certainly a place to return with some friends, hopefully the service will be faster.

Delicious fusion sushi done right. Every piece was carefully balanced and used local ingredients in a way that was creative and delicious. Textures and flavours were varied and exciting! Plus the set menus are very well priced for the amount of food you get and the artistry that goes into them! Difficult to figure out how to get in if you arrive early--the door is red with no sign on it, but it will open when the restaurant opens!
Very creative Japanese restaurant, the service was impeccable and the prices reasonable.

Best coffee we've had in 12 days. I had Vietnamese black coffee and my wife had espresso. We both thought ours were excellent. Can't speak for the food but good aircon and a nice place to sit mid gallery visit.
đồ ăn ngon , rất vừa miệng, sẽ tiếp tục quay lại đây
Đồ ăn ngon

Great little cozy family restaurant. We ate on the patio area where there's stray cats roaming about and many old bonsai-like plants. The owner was very friendly and often joined us for conversation. The main attraction is of course, the food presentation. Many dishes are created to look like the Phoenix. Plates are "tapas" style and shared. Foods are easy to eat if you are not used to eating weird dishes in Vietnam. Definitely no need to shy away, nothing unusual. Overall, food was good and dining experience was very photo worthy.

Hue city is known for its famous 'imperial cuisine', which is a beautiful part of Vietnamese culinary history. Yet, it's quite impossible to actually enjoy it since no way any of the present restaurants can meet the requirements of the cuisine. So, I'm trying to be fair with the place. 
This restaurant is beautiful, zen like, stuck in a quiet, charming alley near the Palace's inner areas. It'd be nice to have a polite, cultural dinner. The food are decent, plus presenting on 'fancy' plating. Only set menus though.

Imperial City Dining in Hue !!

Visiting the Imperial City demands that you experience it like royalty. This restaurant makes you feel like you were the king himself. All the dishes were impeccable and detailed. Almost too good to eat...for about a minute. After photographing the food, you can truly taste Hue. 

Also enjoy the gardens before and after your meal.
A very beautiful place to be. Quite, peaceful, amazing garden providing fresh air. Although, the food wasnt as pleasant.

Pro for the nice garden...otherwise you may rely on the reviews below. What you are paying for is 2 hours of serenity in a garden that's very far away from the town's bustle. If that's worth your 30 USD, then hide there for a bit. Good food can be found elsewhere, and you didn't come to Vietnam for inedible decorations.
